name: Kashmiri Al Yakhni Recipe

ingredients.name: bottle gourd (lauki)
ingredients.quantity: 500g (estimated from video slicing at 1:27 and cooking at 1:55, assuming a medium-sized lauki is used.)

ingredients.name: yogurt
ingredients.quantity: 2 cups (estimated from video whisking at 3:10 and finishing gravy at 5:10, assuming a generous amount for creamy gravy.)

ingredients.name: ginger-garlic paste
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for flavor base.)

ingredients.name: cumin seeds
ingredients.quantity: 1 tsp (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for tempering.)

ingredients.name: fennel powder
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for Kashmiri cuisine.)

ingredients.name: dry ginger powder
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 tsp (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for Kashmiri cuisine.)

ingredients.name: green cardamom
ingredients.quantity: 2-3 pods (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for flavoring.)

ingredients.name: cloves
ingredients.quantity: 2-3 (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for flavoring.)

ingredients.name: bay leaf
ingredients.quantity: 1 (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for flavoring.)

ingredients.name: oil or ghee
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for cooking.)

ingredients.name: salt
ingredients.quantity: to taste (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for seasoning.)

ingredients.name: turmeric powder
ingredients.quantity: 1/4 tsp (estimated, based on common Indian cooking practices for color and health benefits.)

instructions: Slice the bottle gourd (lauki) into small pieces (as seen in the video at 1:27).
Heat oil or ghee in a pot.
Add cumin seeds, bay leaf, cloves, and cardamom to the hot oil and let them splutter.
Add ginger-garlic paste and saute for a minute.
Add the sliced bottle gourd and turmeric powder; cook for a few minutes (as seen in the video at 1:55).
In a separate bowl, whisk the yogurt well to prevent curdling (as seen in the video at 3:10).
Slowly add the whisked yogurt to the pot while stirring continuously.
Add fennel powder, dry ginger powder, and salt to taste.
Simmer the gravy until the bottle gourd is cooked and the gravy thickens (as seen in the video at 5:10).
Serve hot with steamed quinoa or rice.
description: Comforting Kashmiri Al Yakhni recipe, featuring tender bottle gourd in a creamy yogurt gravy.

name: Tangy & Spicy Chunky Pineapple Chutney

ingredients.name: pineapple
ingredients.quantity: 1 medium, chopped into chunks (approximately 2 cups chopped chunks )

instructions: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add cumin seeds and mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Add asafoetida and turmeric powder. Sauté for a few seconds.
Add chopped ginger and green chilies. Sauté for a minute until the raw smell disappears.
Add the chopped pineapple and salt. Mix well.
Add jaggery and lemon juice. Stir to combine.
Cook on medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the pineapple softens and the chutney thickens to your desired consistency (about 20-25 minutes).
Taste and adjust seasoning if needed.
Once the chutney has cooled, store it in an airtight container in the refrigerator.
description: A delicious mix of sweet, tangy, and spicy flavors made with pineapple, lemon, jaggery, and spices.

name: Pressure Cooker Quinoa

ingredients.name: quinoa
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (or as needed, inferred from recipe description for fluffy quinoa every time.)

ingredients.name: water
ingredients.quantity: 2 cups (inferred, double the amount of quinoa for cooking in a pressure cooker)

ingredients.name: salt
ingredients.quantity: to taste (inferred, seasoning for the quinoa)

instructions: Rinse the quinoa thoroughly under cold water.
Add the rinsed quinoa and water to the pressure cooker.
Add salt to taste.
Close the pressure cooker lid and cook for a whistle or the specified time for your pressure cooker.
Once cooked, let the pressure release naturally.
Fluff the quinoa with a fork before serving.
description: Simple recipe to cook fluffy quinoa in a pressure cooker. Quick, nutritious, and versatile. Serve it along with dal, sambar, rasam or make salads, upma, poha etc with this cooked quinoa.

name: Gobi Matar ki Sabzi
instructions: Heat oil in a pan or kadai.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add chopped tomato and cook until soft.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and coriander powder. Sauté for a minute.
Add cauliflower florets and peas. Mix well.
Add salt to taste and mix well.
Cover and cook until the cauliflower is tender, about 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with Thepla, Gujarati Dal, Quinoa Foxtail Millet Rice and Spicy Tomato Pickle.

name: Homemade Sour Cream

ingredients.name: heavy cream
ingredients.quantity: 2 cups (approximately, based on standard sour cream recipes and video description of 'creamy' texture.) Adjust to desired consistency.)

ingredients.name: lemon juice or vinegar
ingredients.quantity: 2 tablespoons (approximately, based on standard sour cream recipes. Adjust to taste.)

instructions: Combine heavy cream and lemon juice (or vinegar) in a clean glass jar or bowl.
Stir well to combine.
Cover loosely with a lid or cheesecloth secured with a rubber band.
Let the mixture sit at room temperature (around 70-75°F or 21-24°C) for 24-48 hours, or until it thickens to your desired consistency. The warmer the room, the faster it will thicken.
Check the sour cream periodically. It should thicken and develop a slightly tangy aroma.
Once it has thickened, stir well and refrigerate for at least 2 hours to stop the culturing process and further thicken the sour cream.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 1-2 weeks.
description: Easy homemade sour cream using heavy cream and lemon juice or vinegar.

name: Vazhaithandu Poriyal

ingredients.name: banana stem
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup chopped finely (inferred from recipe type and common ingredients for poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: urad dal
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: mustard seeds
ingredients.quantity: 1 tsp (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: dry red chilies
ingredients.quantity: 2-3 (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: curry leaves
ingredients.quantity: 1 sprig (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: grated coconut
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: salt
ingredients.quantity: to taste (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

ingredients.name: oil
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp (inferred from poriyal recipes, assuming a standard serving size is made.)

instructions: Prepare the banana stem by finely chopping it and removing any fibrous strands.
Heat oil in a pan.
Add mustard seeds and allow them to splutter.
Add urad dal and dry red chilies, and sauté until the dal turns light brown.
Add curry leaves and sauté for a few seconds.
Add the chopped banana stem and salt.
Sauté well and cover the pan. Cook until the banana stem is tender, stirring occasionally.
Add grated coconut and mix well.
Cook for another minute and remove from heat.
Serve hot as a side dish with rice and kootu.
description: Vazhaithandu Poriyal recipe is a delectable banana stem curry crafted without onion and garlic, perfect for those seeking a lighter, yet equally flavorsome, meal option. Served alongside a comforting Poricha Kootu and fluffy rice, this meal offers a harmonious blend of textures and flavors, sure to satisfy your cravings for a hearty yet nutritious lunch or dinner.

name: Carrot Poriyal

ingredients.name: Carrots
ingredients.quantity: Fresh carrots (amount not specified, infer quantity based on servings desired.) Suggest 2-3 medium carrots for 2 servings.)

ingredients.name: Aromatic Spices
ingredients.quantity: Amount not specified. Infer spices typically used in Indian cooking such as mustard seeds, cumin seeds, turmeric powder, red chili powder, asafoetida (hing). Quantities to taste.

ingredients.name: Grated Coconut
ingredients.quantity: Amount not specified. Suggest 1/4 to 1/2 cup depending on preference.

instructions: Prepare the carrots by washing, peeling, and chopping or grating them.
Heat oil in a pan or kadai.
Add mustard seeds and allow them to splutter. If using, add urad dal and chana dal and saute until golden brown.
Add curry leaves and asafoetida (hing).
Add the chopped or grated carrots to the pan.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Stir well to combine the spices with the carrots.
Cover the pan and cook until the carrots are tender, stirring occasionally to prevent burning.
Once the carrots are cooked, add the grated coconut.
Mix well and cook for another minute or two.
Serve hot as a side dish with rice or roti.
description: Carrot Poriyal is a popular Indian vegetable recipe that features fresh carrots cooked with aromatic spices and grated coconut. This recipe is not only healthy but also quick to prepare, making it an ideal choice for busy weeknights or a comforting meal.

name: Kesar Shrikhand

ingredients.name: Plain Curd
ingredients.quantity: 1 Kg (1000g/35 oz.) drained to about 400-500g of hung curd/yogurt cheese/chakka )

ingredients.name: Saffron strands
ingredients.quantity: 1 large pinch (soaked in warm milk or water)

instructions: Hang the curd in a muslin cloth for several hours or overnight to drain all the whey.
Once the curd is strained, collect the thick yogurt in a bowl.
Powder the sugar using a grinder.
Add the powdered sugar to the strained yogurt.
Mix well until the sugar is completely dissolved and the mixture is smooth.
Add cardamom powder (optional) and saffron strands soaked in warm milk or water.
Mix everything well.
Garnish with chopped or pounded pistachios.
Refrigerate for at least 2-3 hours before serving to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve chilled as a dessert, optionally with warm puris.
description: A traditional Gujarati and Maharashtrian dessert made from strained yogurt, sugar, and saffron.

Prepare the tamarind paste by soaking tamarind in warm water and extracting the pulp.

name: Jeera Rice (Pulao)

ingredients.name: rice
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup uncooked rice (estimated based on common pulao recipes; not explicitly stated in provided text, assuming long grain like basmati for pulao texture.) Note: quantity to be determined based on desired serving size. Adjust water accordingly for cooking. For example, 1 cup rice to 2 cups water is a common ratio, but may vary based on type of rice used and desired consistency.)

ingredients.name: cumin seeds (jeera)
ingredients.quantity: 1-2 teaspoons (estimated based on common pulao recipes; not explicitly stated in provided text, but jeera is the defining ingredient.)

ingredients.name: ghee or oil
ingredients.quantity: 1-2 tablespoons (estimated based on common pulao recipes; not explicitly stated in provided text, but necessary for tempering the cumin.)

ingredients.name: water
ingredients.quantity: 2 cups (estimated based on common pulao recipes; not explicitly stated in provided text, assuming a 2:1 water to rice ratio. Adjust based on rice type.)

ingredients.name: salt
ingredients.quantity: to taste (estimated based on common pulao recipes; not explicitly stated in provided text, but essential for flavor.)

instructions: Rinse the rice under cold water until the water runs clear. This helps remove excess starch and prevents the rice from becoming sticky.
Heat ghee or oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. This releases their aroma and flavor.
Add the rinsed rice and salt to the pan. Sauté for a minute or two.
Add water and bring to a boil.
Once boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the pan, and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the rice is cooked and the water is absorbed.
Once cooked, fluff the rice with a fork and let it rest for a few minutes before serving.
description: Simple rice recipe with roasted cumin and ghee, ready in less than 20 minutes. A popular North Indian dish, perfect with dals, kadhi, rajma, or chole.

name: Arachuvitta Sambar

ingredients.name: Spices (freshly ground)
ingredients.quantity: as needed for sambar masala paste (toor dal, coriander seeds, cumin seeds, dried red chilies, fenugreek seeds, black peppercorns, asafoetida, turmeric powder, curry leaves, mustard seeds, urad dal, chana dal, oil for tempering, tamarind extract, salt, sambar powder, vegetables of your choice (drumstick, okra, brinjal, pumpkin, etc.), coconut (grated), coriander leaves (for garnish))

ingredients.name: Toor Dal
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 cup (for sambar masala paste and sambar preparation), category: Pantry

ingredients.name: Coriander Seeds
ingredients.quantity: 2 tablespoons (for sambar masala paste), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Cumin Seeds
ingredients.quantity: 1 teaspoon (for sambar masala paste), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Dried Red Chilies
ingredients.quantity: 6-8 (adjust to taste, for sambar masala paste), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Fenugreek Seeds
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 teaspoon (for sambar masala paste), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Black Peppercorns
ingredients.quantity: 1/4 teaspoon (for sambar masala paste), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Asafoetida
ingredients.quantity: a pinch (for sambar masala paste and tempering), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Turmeric Powder
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 teaspoon (for sambar masala paste and sambar preparation), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Curry Leaves
ingredients.quantity: 1 sprig (for sambar masala paste and tempering), category: Produce

ingredients.name: Sambar Powder
ingredients.quantity: 1 tablespoon (optional, for extra flavor), category: Spices

ingredients.name: Coconut (grated)
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 cup (for sambar masala paste), category: Produce

instructions: First, prepare the sambar masala paste: In a pan, dry roast toor dal, coriander seeds, cumin seeds, dried red chilies, fenugreek seeds, and black peppercorns until fragrant.
Grind the roasted spices along with grated coconut, asafoetida, turmeric powder, and a little water to form a smooth paste.
Cook the toor dal separately until soft and mash it well.
In a pot, add the chopped vegetables, tamarind extract, salt, turmeric powder, and sambar powder (if using). Cook until the vegetables are partially tender.
Add the cooked and mashed toor dal to the pot. Bring to a simmer.
Add the freshly ground sambar masala paste to the pot. Mix well and simmer for 10-15 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together.
Prepare the tempering: Heat oil in a small pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, chana dal, curry leaves, and a pinch of asafoetida. Allow the mustard seeds to splutter.
Pour the tempering over the sambar. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve the Arachuvitta Sambar hot with steamed rice, ghee, and other South Indian dishes like Keerai Thoran, Urali Roast, and Elai Vadam.
description: A delicious Arachuvitta Sambar made from freshly ground spices and coconut.

name: Dry Mushroom Manchurian

ingredients.name: Mushrooms
ingredients.quantity: 200g sliced or quartered depending on size of mushrooms (button or oyster mushrooms work well). Adjust quantity as needed for desired serving size.)

ingredients.name: All-purpose flour (Maida)
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (for coating the mushrooms, can substitute with cornstarch for a gluten-free option)

ingredients.name: Cornstarch
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp (for coating the mushrooms, helps in getting a crispy texture)

ingredients.name: Water
ingredients.quantity: as needed (for making a slurry with flour and cornstarch)

instructions: Prepare the Mushrooms: Wash and slice or quarter the mushrooms. Ensure they are dry before coating.
Make the Coating: In a bowl, mix together all-purpose flour, cornstarch, salt, and black pepper powder. Add a little water to make a thick slurry.
Coat the Mushrooms: Dip each mushroom piece into the slurry, ensuring it is well coated.
Fry the Mushrooms: Heat cooking oil in a pan or deep fryer. Fry the coated mushrooms until golden brown and crispy. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Prepare the Sauce: In a separate pan or wok, heat a little cooking oil. Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies. Sauté for a minute until fragrant.
Sauté Vegetables: Add chopped onion and capsicum. Sauté until the onions turn translucent.
Add Sauces: Add soy sauce, chili sauce, tomato ketchup, and vinegar to the pan. Mix well.
Thicken the Sauce: If the sauce is too thick, add a little water to adjust consistency. Bring to a simmer.
Add Fried Mushrooms: Add the fried mushrooms to the sauce. Toss gently to coat the mushrooms evenly with the sauce.
Garnish and Serve: Garnish with chopped spring onions. Serve hot as an appetizer or side dish.
description: Lip smacking, super delicious and healthy Dry Mushroom Manchurian Recipe

instructions: Combine rice flour, black pepper, sesame seeds, and salt in a bowl.
Add water gradually and mix to form a dough.
Divide the dough into small portions and flatten each portion into a thin disc.
Heat oil in a pan for deep frying.
Carefully slide the flattened thattai into the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crispy.

Serve Milagu Thattai as a snack with coffee.

name: Ragi Mudde (Ragi Balls)

ingredients.name: ragi flour
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup + a few tablespoons for slurry (estimated 2 tbsp.) + more for dusting hands (optional). Total estimated 1.25 cups or 150g approx.)

ingredients.name: water
ingredients.quantity: 2 cups + a few tablespoons for slurry (estimated 4 tbsp.)

ingredients.name: ghee
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp or more to taste (optional, for flavouring and shaping the balls). Total estimated 1 tbsp.

instructions: Add a few tablespoons of ragi flour to a small bowl and mix with a few tablespoons of water to make a slurry.
In a pan, bring 2 cups of water to a boil. Add salt to taste.
Once the water is boiling, reduce the heat to low and slowly pour in the ragi flour slurry while stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Stir to combine the flour and water until a smooth mixture is formed.
Cover the pan and let it rest for 3 to 4 minutes on low heat.
After resting, stir the mixture vigorously until it forms a thick dough-like consistency and starts to leave the sides of the pan.
Add ghee to the dough and mix well. This step is optional but adds flavor and helps in shaping the balls.
Turn off the heat and let the mixture cool slightly until it is manageable to handle.
Grease your hands with ghee or water (or dust with ragi flour) to prevent sticking.
Take a portion of the ragi mixture and shape it into a smooth, round ball.
Repeat with the remaining mixture.
Serve the ragi mudde hot with Soppu Saaru, Rasam, or Curry for lunch or dinner.
description: A high protein dish made from ragi flour, cooked and flavored with ghee, and shaped into balls. A wholesome diabetic-friendly recipe.

name: Tilkut Ladoo

ingredients.name: Sesame seeds (Til)
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (estimated based on common recipes for Tilkut Ladoo, adjust as needed for desired quantity.)

ingredients.name: Jaggery (Gud)
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (estimated based on common recipes for Tilkut Ladoo, adjust as needed for desired quantity.)

instructions: Prepare the sesame seeds: Lightly roast the sesame seeds in a pan until they turn slightly golden and aromatic. Be careful not to burn them.
Prepare the jaggery: Grate or finely chop the jaggery into small pieces. This will help it melt evenly.
Melt the jaggery: In a pan, melt the grated jaggery over low heat. Stir continuously to prevent burning. Melt it until it becomes sticky and forms a soft ball consistency when dropped in water.
Combine sesame seeds and jaggery: Add the roasted sesame seeds to the melted jaggery and mix well, ensuring that the sesame seeds are evenly coated with the jaggery.

Shape the ladoos: While the mixture is still warm, take small portions of the mixture and shape them into round ladoos using your hands. Grease your palms with a little ghee or oil to prevent sticking.
Cool and store: Allow the ladoos to cool completely before storing them in an airtight container. This will help them retain their shape and prevent them from becoming sticky.
description: Tilkut ke Ladoo is a traditional Indian sweet made with sesame seeds and jaggery, especially popular during winter and Makar Sankranti. This recipe provides tips to make soft, fluffy, and non-sticky ladoos.

name: Til Gud Ladoo (Sesame Jaggery Balls)

ingredients.name: Sesame seeds (Til)
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (approx. 150g-200g, adjust to preference based on jaggery sweetness and desired consistency.) Note: White sesame seeds are typically used, but black sesame seeds can also be incorporated for added flavor and nutrients. Roasting the sesame seeds enhances their nutty flavor and reduces any bitterness. Be careful not to burn them during roasting, as this will make them taste bitter. For a smoother texture, you can lightly grind a portion of the sesame seeds after roasting. This is optional but helps the ladoos bind better. Some recipes call for soaking the sesame seeds before roasting to remove impurities and improve digestibility. This is not essential but can be done if desired. If soaking, ensure the seeds are thoroughly dried before roasting. If you prefer a richer flavor, you can add a tablespoon or two of desiccated coconut or chopped nuts like almonds or cashews to the sesame seeds before roasting. This will also add texture to the ladoos. To prevent the sesame seeds from sticking to the pan during roasting, use a non-stick pan or add a teaspoon of ghee or oil to the pan before adding the seeds. Stir constantly to ensure even roasting. The sesame seeds are roasted when they turn light golden brown and start to pop. Remove them from the heat immediately to prevent burning. If you're using black sesame seeds, it can be harder to tell when they're roasted. Look for a change in aroma and a slightly more brittle texture. You can also taste a few seeds to check for doneness. If you want to add a hint of spice to your ladoos, you can add a pinch of cardamom powder or ginger powder to the sesame seeds after roasting. This is optional but adds a nice flavor complexity. To make the ladoos easier to shape, you can add a tablespoon or two of milk or water to the sesame-jaggery mixture while it's still warm. This will help bind the ingredients together and make the ladoos more pliable. Be careful not to add too much liquid, as this will make the ladoos sticky. If you're having trouble shaping the ladoos, you can lightly grease your hands with ghee or oil. This will prevent the mixture from sticking to your hands. To store the ladoos, keep them in an airtight container at room temperature. They will stay fresh for several weeks. If you live in a warm climate, you can store them in the refrigerator to prevent them from becoming sticky. When making til ladoos, it's important to use good quality jaggery. Jaggery is unrefined sugar made from sugarcane juice or palm sap. It's a healthier alternative to refined sugar and adds a unique flavor to the ladoos. Look for jaggery that is dark brown in color and has a firm texture. Avoid jaggery that is pale or sticky, as this may be of poor quality. There are different types of jaggery available in the market, such as sugarcane jaggery, palm jaggery, and date jaggery. Each type has a slightly different flavor and texture. You can use any type of jaggery for making til ladoos, but sugarcane jaggery is the most commonly used type. To prepare the jaggery, you'll need to grate it or chop it into small pieces. This will help it melt evenly when heated. You can also use jaggery powder if you prefer. If you're using jaggery that is very hard, you can soften it by microwaving it for a few seconds or by steaming it over a pot of boiling water. Be careful not to overheat the jaggery, as this will make it hard and difficult to work with. When melting the jaggery, it's important to stir it constantly to prevent it from burning. You can add a tablespoon or two of water to the jaggery to help it melt more easily. Once the jaggery is melted, cook it for a few minutes until it thickens slightly. This will help the ladoos bind better. To test if the jaggery is ready, drop a small amount into a bowl of cold water. If it forms a firm ball, it's ready. If it dissolves in the water, it needs to be cooked for a few more minutes. If you're using a microwave to melt the jaggery, heat it in short intervals, stirring in between, to prevent it from burning. Be careful when handling hot jaggery, as it can cause burns. Use oven mitts or a silicone spatula to protect your hands. If you're making a large batch of til ladoos, you may need to melt the jaggery in batches to prevent it from burning. Once the jaggery is melted and cooked, add the roasted sesame seeds and mix well. Make sure the sesame seeds are evenly coated with the jaggery. Allow the mixture to cool slightly before shaping the ladoos. This will make it easier to handle. If the mixture becomes too hard to shape, you can warm it up slightly over low heat. To shape the ladoos, take a small amount of the mixture in your hands and roll it into a ball. You can make the ladoos any size you like, but they are typically about 1-2 inches in diameter. Place the ladoos on a plate or tray to cool completely. Once they are cool, they will be firm and easy to handle. If you want to add a decorative touch to your til ladoos, you can roll them in sesame seeds, desiccated coconut, or chopped nuts before they cool completely. This will give them a nice texture and visual appeal. Til ladoos are a popular Indian sweet that is traditionally made during the winter months. They are a good source of energy and nutrients and are a delicious way to warm up on a cold day. They are also a popular offering during Hindu festivals such as Makar Sankranti. Til ladoos are relatively easy to make and can be customized to your liking. You can add different types of nuts, spices, and flavorings to create your own unique version. They are also a good option for people who are looking for a gluten-free or dairy-free sweet treat. If you have any leftover til ladoos, you can store them in an airtight container at room temperature for several weeks. They can also be frozen for longer storage. To thaw frozen til ladoos, simply leave them at room temperature for a few hours. Til ladoos are a delicious and nutritious sweet that is perfect for any occasion. They are easy to make, customizable, and can be enjoyed by people of all ages. So, next time you're looking for a sweet treat, give til ladoos a try!

ingredients.name: Ghee (Clarified Butter)
ingredients.quantity: 1 tsp (Optional, for greasing hands or pan.) Note: Ghee is traditionally used in til ladoos for its flavor and health benefits. However, you can substitute it with butter or oil if you prefer. Ghee adds a rich, nutty flavor to the ladoos. It also helps to bind the ingredients together and makes the ladoos easier to shape. If you're using butter, use unsalted butter. If you're using oil, use a neutral-flavored oil such as vegetable oil or canola oil. You can also use coconut oil for a slightly different flavor. If you're using ghee, melt it before adding it to the sesame-jaggery mixture. This will help it mix more evenly. You can melt the ghee in a microwave or in a saucepan over low heat. Be careful not to overheat the ghee, as this will cause it to burn. If you're using butter, melt it in the same way as ghee. If you're using oil, you don't need to melt it. Simply add it to the sesame-jaggery mixture as is. When adding ghee, butter, or oil to the sesame-jaggery mixture, start with a small amount and add more as needed. You want the mixture to be moist enough to bind together, but not so wet that it becomes sticky. If you're using ghee or butter, you can also use it to grease your hands before shaping the ladoos. This will prevent the mixture from sticking to your hands. If you're using oil, you can also use it to grease the pan before roasting the sesame seeds. This will prevent the sesame seeds from sticking to the pan. Ghee, butter, and oil are all good sources of fat. Fat is an essential nutrient that helps our bodies absorb vitamins and minerals. It also provides us with energy and helps to keep us feeling full. However, it's important to consume fat in moderation. Too much fat can lead to weight gain and other health problems. When choosing a fat to use in til ladoos, consider your dietary needs and preferences. If you're looking for a healthy option, ghee is a good choice. It's a good source of saturated fat, which is important for hormone production and cell function. If you're looking for a vegan option, oil is a good choice. Just be sure to choose a neutral-flavored oil so that it doesn't overpower the flavor of the ladoos. No matter which fat you choose, be sure to use it in moderation. Til ladoos are a delicious and nutritious treat, but they should be enjoyed as part of a balanced diet.

ingredients.name: Cardamom Powder
ingredients.quantity: Pinch (Optional, for flavor.) Note: Cardamom powder is a popular spice that is used in many Indian sweets. It has a sweet, floral aroma and a slightly spicy flavor. If you're using cardamom powder, add it to the sesame-jaggery mixture after the jaggery has melted. Start with a small amount and add more as needed. You can also add other spices to the sesame-jaggery mixture, such as ginger powder, nutmeg powder, or cinnamon powder. These spices will add a warm, spicy flavor to the ladoos. If you're using whole cardamom pods, you'll need to grind them into a powder before adding them to the sesame-jaggery mixture. You can grind them in a spice grinder or in a mortar and pestle. Be sure to remove the husks from the cardamom pods before grinding them. Cardamom powder is a good source of antioxidants. Antioxidants are compounds that help protect our bodies from damage caused by free radicals. Free radicals are unstable molecules that can damage cells and contribute to aging and disease. Cardamom powder is also a good source of minerals, such as potassium, calcium, and magnesium. These minerals are important for maintaining healthy bones, muscles, and nerves. When choosing cardamom powder, look for a powder that is fresh and fragrant. Avoid powders that are dull or have a musty smell. You can store cardamom powder in an airtight container in a cool, dark place for up to six months. If you're using whole cardamom pods, you can store them in an airtight container in a cool, dark place for up to a year. Cardamom powder is a delicious and nutritious spice that can add flavor and health benefits to til ladoos. It's a good source of antioxidants and minerals, and it has a sweet, floral aroma and a slightly spicy flavor. So, next time you're making til ladoos, be sure to add a pinch of cardamom powder for a delicious and healthy treat!

instructions: Roast the sesame seeds in a pan until they turn light golden brown.

instructions: Take 400g of potatoes, boil them, peel them and mash them well.

Add 2.5 tsp of salt, 2 cups (100g) of fenugreek leaves, 2 cups (100g) of spinach, 1.5 cups (150g) of gram flour, 2 green chilies (chopped), 1 tsp of ginger paste, 1/2 tsp of turmeric powder, 1 tsp of red chili powder, 1 tsp of coriander powder, 1 tsp of roasted cumin powder, 1/2 tsp of garam masala, and 1/2 tsp of dry mango powder to the mashed potatoes.
Mix all the ingredients well to form a dough.
Heat oil in a pan for frying.
Take a small portion of the dough and shape it into a small tikki (patty).
Gently slide the tikki into the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crispy on both sides.
Remove the tikki from the oil and place it on a paper towel to drain excess oil.

To make the chutney, combine 1 cup (50g) of green coriander, 50g of radish leaves, 2 green chilies, 1 inch of ginger, 1 tbsp of lemon juice, 1/4 tsp of salt, 1/2 tsp of black salt, and 1 tsp of roasted cumin powder in a blender.
Blend all the ingredients until smooth.
To assemble the chaat, place the crispy tikki on a plate.
Top with the prepared chutney.
Serve immediately and enjoy!
description: Punjabi Winter Street Food with Desi Spices. Crispy tikki made from methi and aloo, topped with a flavorful chutney.

ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (soaked overnight preferred, or pressure cook until tender). Add to pot with other ingredients.)

ingredients.name: Pearl millet (Bajra)
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (50 grams). Add to pot with other ingredients.)

ingredients.name: Rice
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (50 grams). Add to pot with other ingredients.)

ingredients.name: Tomato
ingredients.quantity: 2 no (200 grams, chopped). Add to pot.)

ingredients.name: Coriander
ingredients.quantity: To garnish (fresh, chopped). Garnish after cooking.)

instructions: Heat ghee in a pot.
Add cumin seeds and asafoetida.
Add ginger chilli paste and chopped tomatoes.
Add turmeric powder, Kashmiri red chilli powder, and salt.
Add desi chickpeas, green peas, moth lentil, sabut moong, bajra, and rice.
Add water (approximately 4-5 cups) and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer until all grains and lentils are cooked and the khichda reaches a desired consistency (about 20-30 minutes).
Garnish with fresh coriander before serving.
description: A one-pot winter meal made with whole grains and desi spices, perfect for warmth and health.

name: Moong Dal Stuffed Cheela

ingredients.name: Moong Dal
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (soaked overnight or for at least 4 hours, then drained.)

instructions: Soak moong dal and rice for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Grind the soaked moong dal, rice, green chili, ginger, asafoetida, and salt into a smooth batter.
For the stuffing, heat oil in a pan.
Add cumin seeds, ginger chilli paste, and asafoetida to the oil and saute.
Add boiled and mashed potatoes, chopped tomatoes, and salt to the pan and mix well. Cook until the mixture is heated through.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the hot pan and spread it into a thin circle.
Cook the cheela until one side is lightly golden.
Spread the potato stuffing evenly over the cheela.
Fold the cheela in half or into a roll.
Cook until both sides are golden brown and crispy.
Serve hot.
description: Protein-rich breakfast or snack made from moong dal and stuffed with a spiced potato mixture.

name: Til-Gud ki Burfi (Sesame and Jaggery Sweet)

ingredients.name: Sesame seeds (Til)
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (approx. 150g-200g, adjust to preference and recipe size.)

ingredients.name: Jaggery (Gud)
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (approx. 150g-200g, adjust to preference and recipe size.)

ingredients.name: Ghee (Clarified Butter)
ingredients.quantity: 1-2 teaspoons (for greasing the surface and optional addition to the burfi for richness.)

instructions: Lightly roast the sesame seeds in a pan over medium heat until they turn slightly golden and aromatic. Be careful not to burn them. Remove from pan and set aside.
In the same pan, melt the jaggery over low heat. Stir continuously to prevent burning. Add a teaspoon of ghee if desired for a smoother texture.

Continue to cook the jaggery until it reaches a one-string consistency. To test, drop a small amount of melted jaggery into a bowl of water. It should form a soft, pliable ball that can be stretched into a single string.
Once the jaggery reaches the correct consistency, immediately add the roasted sesame seeds to the pan and mix well to combine. Work quickly as the jaggery will start to harden.
Grease a flat surface (such as a baking sheet or a plate) with ghee. Pour the sesame-jaggery mixture onto the greased surface and spread it evenly with a spatula or rolling pin.
While the mixture is still warm, cut it into desired shapes (squares, diamonds, etc.) using a knife or pizza cutter.
Allow the burfi to cool completely and harden before breaking it into pieces and storing it in an airtight container.
description: A traditional Indian sweet made with sesame seeds and jaggery, perfect for winter.

name: Beetroot Paneer Cutlets

ingredients.name: beetroot
ingredients.quantity: 4 no. (250g), peeled and grated or finely chopped. Cooked or raw are both acceptable. If raw, ensure it is finely grated or chopped to ensure even cooking during the shallow frying process. If cooked, the cutlets will be softer and may require more breadcrumbs to bind the mixture together. If using cooked beetroot, reduce the cooking time of the cutlets slightly to prevent them from becoming too dry. Ensure the beetroot is not too watery before adding it to the mixture. If it is, squeeze out any excess moisture using a clean kitchen towel or muslin cloth. This will help prevent the cutlets from becoming soggy and falling apart during cooking. If using raw beetroot, add a little bit of water while cooking the beetroot mixture to prevent it from sticking to the pan and to ensure that it cooks through evenly. Be mindful of the cooking time as raw beetroot will take longer to cook than cooked beetroot. Keep an eye on the color of the beetroot while cooking. It should become more vibrant and slightly translucent when it is cooked through. If the beetroot is still hard or crunchy, continue cooking it for a few more minutes until it is tender but not mushy. Taste the beetroot before adding it to the mixture to ensure that it is not bitter. If it is, you can add a little bit of sugar or lemon juice to balance out the flavor. Remember to adjust the amount of spices and seasonings according to your taste preferences. You can add more or less ginger-chili paste, salt, turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, dry mango powder, black pepper, and cumin powder to achieve the desired flavor profile. If you want to add a touch of sweetness to the cutlets, you can add a small amount of grated carrot or sweet potato to the beetroot mixture. This will also add a pleasant texture and color to the cutlets. If you are using cooked beetroot, you can mash it slightly with a fork before adding it to the mixture to create a smoother texture. This will also help the cutlets hold their shape better during cooking. If you are using raw beetroot, you can grate it using a food processor or a box grater. This will save you time and effort, especially if you are making a large batch of cutlets. If you don't have fresh beetroot, you can use canned beetroot instead. However, make sure to drain it well and rinse it under cold water before adding it to the mixture to remove any excess salt or preservatives. If you want to make the cutlets vegan, you can replace the paneer with crumbled tofu or mashed potatoes. You can also add some chopped nuts or seeds to the mixture for added texture and nutrition. If you are allergic to gluten, you can use gluten-free breadcrumbs or ground almonds instead of regular breadcrumbs. You can also add some chickpea flour or rice flour to the mixture to help bind it together. If you want to make the cutlets ahead of time, you can prepare the beetroot and paneer mixtures separately and store them in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours. When you are ready to cook the cutlets, simply combine the mixtures, shape them into cutlets, and shallow fry them until golden brown and crispy. If you have any leftover cutlets, you can store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. To reheat them, you can microwave them, bake them in the oven, or pan-fry them until heated through and crispy. If you want to freeze the cutlets for longer storage, you can freeze them uncooked on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Once they are frozen solid, transfer them to a freezer bag or container and store them in the freezer for up to 2 months. When you are ready to cook the frozen cutlets, you can thaw them in the refrigerator overnight or cook them directly from frozen. However, you may need to adjust the cooking time accordingly. If you are cooking the cutlets directly from frozen, make sure to cook them over low heat to prevent them from burning on the outside while remaining frozen on the inside. You can also cover the pan with a lid to help them cook through evenly. If you want to make the cutlets more nutritious, you can add some chopped spinach, kale, or other leafy greens to the beetroot mixture. This will add extra vitamins, minerals, and fiber to the cutlets. If you want to make the cutlets more flavorful, you can add some chopped herbs such as cilantro, mint, or parsley to the beetroot mixture. This will add a fresh and aromatic touch to the cutlets. If you want to make the cutlets more visually appealing, you can coat them with sesame seeds, poppy seeds, or chopped nuts before shallow frying them. This will add a crunchy texture and a decorative touch to the cutlets. If you want to make the cutlets more kid-friendly, you can shape them into fun shapes such as stars, hearts, or animals using cookie cutters. This will make them more appealing to children and encourage them to try new foods. If you want to make the cutlets more elegant, you can serve them with a dipping sauce such as mint chutney, tamarind chutney, or raita. This will add a burst of flavor and moisture to the cutlets. If you want to make the cutlets more festive, you can serve them as part of a vegetarian platter or appetizer spread. This will add a colorful and nutritious element to your party or gathering. If you want to make the cutlets more sustainable, you can use locally sourced and seasonal ingredients whenever possible. This will reduce your carbon footprint and support local farmers and producers. If you want to make the cutlets more ethical, you can choose organic and fair-trade ingredients whenever possible. This will ensure that the ingredients are produced in a way that is environmentally and socially responsible. If you want to make the cutlets more accessible, you can share the recipe with your friends and family and encourage them to try it out. This will help spread the joy of cooking and eating healthy and delicious food. If you want to make the cutlets more memorable, you can serve them with a personal touch such as a handwritten note or a small gift. This will show your guests that you care and that you have put thought and effort into preparing the meal. If you want to make the cutlets more meaningful, you can use them as a way to connect with your culture and heritage. This will help you preserve your traditions and share them with future generations. If you want to make the cutlets more impactful, you can use them as a way to support a cause or charity that you care about. This will help you make a positive difference in the world and inspire others to do the same.

instructions: Grate or finely chop the beetroot.
Heat oil in a pan, add ginger chilli paste and sauté for a minute.
Add grated beetroot, salt, turmeric powder, red chilli powder, coriander powder, and dry mango powder. Mix well and cook until the beetroot is tender.
Add mashed potatoes and mix well. Let the mixture cool.
In a separate bowl, crumble the paneer. Add green coriander, black pepper, cumin powder, and salt. Mix well.
Take a small portion of the beetroot mixture and flatten it in your palm.
Place a small amount of the paneer mixture in the center.
Bring the edges of the beetroot mixture together to cover the paneer filling and shape it into a cutlet.
Roll the cutlet in bread crumbs to coat evenly.
Heat a pan with a little oil and shallow fry the cutlets until golden brown on both sides.

name: Crispy Bitter Gourd (Karela) Chips

ingredients.name: Bitter Gourd (Karela)
ingredients.quantity: 2-3 medium size (approximately 250 grams total weight before preparation). Adjust quantity based on preference and size of gourds.)

ingredients.name: Salt
ingredients.quantity: To taste (approximately 1/2 to 1 teaspoon initially, adjust after tasting.)

ingredients.name: Turmeric Powder (Haldi)
ingredients.quantity: 1/4 teaspoon (used for its antiseptic properties and to reduce bitterness.)

ingredients.name: Red Chili Powder (Lal Mirch)
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 teaspoon (adjust to your spice preference. Can substitute with cayenne pepper.)

ingredients.name: Dry Mango Powder (Amchur)
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 teaspoon (adds a tangy flavor that balances the bitterness.)

ingredients.name: Cooking Oil
ingredients.quantity: For deep frying (amount depends on the size of your frying pan or wok.)

instructions: Wash the bitter gourds thoroughly under running water. This helps remove any dirt or residue.
Trim the ends of each bitter gourd. Then, slice them thinly into rounds. Aim for a thickness of about 1/8 inch (3mm) for even cooking and crispiness.
In a bowl, mix the sliced bitter gourd with salt and turmeric powder. Gently massage the mixture to ensure the slices are coated evenly.
Let the bitter gourd slices rest for at least 30 minutes. This process helps draw out excess moisture and bitterness.
After 30 minutes, squeeze the bitter gourd slices to remove the released water. This step is crucial for achieving crispy chips.
In a separate bowl, combine red chili powder, coriander powder, dry mango powder (amchur), and garam masala (if using).
Add the spice mixture to the squeezed bitter gourd slices. Mix well, ensuring the slices are evenly coated with the spices.
Heat cooking oil in a deep frying pan or wok over medium heat. The oil should be hot enough for deep frying, but not smoking.
Carefully add the spiced bitter gourd slices to the hot oil in batches. Avoid overcrowding the pan to maintain the oil temperature.
Fry the bitter gourd slices until they turn golden brown and crispy. This usually takes about 5-7 minutes per batch, depending on the thickness of the slices and the oil temperature.
Remove the fried bitter gourd chips from the oil using a slotted spoon. Place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Once cooled slightly, taste the chips and adjust the seasoning if needed. You can add more salt, chili powder, or amchur to suit your taste.
Serve the crispy bitter gourd chips immediately as a side dish with roti, paratha, or rice. They can also be stored in an airtight container once completely cooled for later enjoyment.
description: Crispy and tasty bitter gourd chips, perfect as a side dish.

name: Suji Moongdal Vada

ingredients.name: Moong dal
ingredients.quantity: 1/2 cup (100 grams) - soaked overnight and drained well before using. Ensure no excess water remains when grinding to a paste. If the batter is too thick, add 1-2 teaspoons of water at a time until the desired consistency is reached. The batter should be thick enough to hold its shape when steamed, but not so thick that it becomes dry or crumbly. If the batter is too thin, add a tablespoon of semolina (suji) at a time until the desired consistency is achieved. Let the batter rest for 5-10 minutes to allow the semolina to absorb the moisture. Do not overmix the batter, as this can make the vadas tough. A smooth, well-combined batter is key to soft and spongy vadas. If the batter is too coarse, grind it for a few more seconds until it reaches the desired consistency. Adjust the amount of ginger-chili paste according to your spice preference. If you prefer a milder flavor, reduce the amount of paste. For a spicier flavor, add more paste or a pinch of red chili powder. If you don't have fresh coriander leaves, you can use dried coriander powder. However, fresh coriander leaves add a more vibrant flavor and aroma to the vadas. If you don't have asafoetida (hing), you can skip it. However, asafoetida adds a unique flavor and aids in digestion. If you don't have Eno, you can use baking soda. However, Eno gives a lighter and fluffier texture to the vadas. If you are using baking soda, use half the amount of Eno and add a pinch of citric acid or lemon juice to activate it. If you are using a steamer without a lid, cover the vadas with a plate while steaming to prevent them from drying out. If you are steaming the vadas in batches, make sure to grease the steaming plate before each batch to prevent the vadas from sticking. If you are using a microwave to steam the vadas, cover them with a microwave-safe lid or plastic wrap to prevent them from drying out. If the vadas are sticking to the steaming plate, gently loosen them with a spatula before removing them. If the vadas are too soft to handle after steaming, let them cool slightly before removing them from the steaming plate. If you are using a non-stick pan to cook the masala vadas, you may need less oil. If you are using a regular pan, make sure to heat the oil properly before adding the mustard seeds and cumin seeds. If the mustard seeds and cumin seeds are not heated properly, they will not splutter and release their flavor. If you don't have curry leaves, you can skip them. However, curry leaves add a unique flavor and aroma to the masala. If you don't have sesame seeds, you can skip them. However, sesame seeds add a nutty flavor and a crunchy texture to the masala. If you don't have Kashmiri red chili powder, you can use regular red chili powder. However, Kashmiri red chili powder gives a vibrant color to the masala without making it too spicy. If you don't have tomato sauce, you can use tomato paste or puree. However, tomato sauce adds a slightly sweet and tangy flavor to the masala. If you don't have sambhar masala, you can use garam masala or any other spice blend of your choice. However, sambhar masala gives a unique flavor to the masala. If you don't have lemon juice, you can use vinegar or amchur powder (dried mango powder). However, lemon juice adds a refreshing tanginess to the masala. If you are using a cast iron pan to cook the masala vadas, make sure to season it properly before use to prevent the vadas from sticking. If you are using a stainless steel pan to cook the masala vadas, make sure to use enough oil to prevent the vadas from sticking. If the masala is too dry, add a tablespoon of water at a time until the desired consistency is reached. If the masala is too watery, cook it for a few more minutes until the excess moisture evaporates. If the vadas are not coated evenly with the masala, gently toss them in the pan until they are well coated. If the vadas are sticking to the pan while coating them with the masala, add a teaspoon of oil to the pan. If the vadas are too hot to handle after coating them with the masala, let them cool slightly before serving. If you are serving the masala vadas immediately, garnish them with fresh coriander leaves and a sprinkle of sesame seeds. If you are serving the masala vadas later, store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Reheat them in a pan or microwave before serving. If you are packing the masala vadas for a tiffin box, wrap them in aluminum foil or parchment paper to prevent them from becoming soggy. If you are making the vadas for a party, you can prepare the batter and steam the vadas in advance. Store the steamed vadas in the refrigerator and coat them with the masala just before serving. If you are making a large batch of masala vadas, you can use a large pan or wok to cook them. If you are using a wok, make sure to stir the vadas constantly to prevent them from sticking to the bottom. If you are making the vadas in a cold climate, you may need to add a little more water to the batter to prevent them from drying out. If you are making the vadas in a humid climate, you may need to add a little more semolina to the batter to prevent them from becoming too soft. If you are using a food processor to grind the moong dal, make sure to pulse it in short bursts to prevent it from becoming too smooth. If you are using a blender to grind the moong dal, make sure to add a little water to help it blend smoothly. If you are using a hand blender to grind the moong dal, make sure to use a deep container to prevent the batter from splattering. instructions: Soak moong dal for a few hours.
Grind the soaked moong dal into a smooth paste.
Add curd, semolina, salt, asafoetida, ginger chilli paste, and coriander to the moong dal paste. Mix well to form a batter.
Add oil and eno to the batter and mix gently.
Shape the batter into vadas.
Steam the vadas until cooked.
Remove the steamed vadas from the steamer.

Prepare masala in a pan by heating oil, mustard seeds, cumin seeds, curry leaves, sesame, turmeric powder, Kashmiri red chilli, tomato sauce, ginger chilli paste, sambhar masala, salt, and lemon juice.
Coat the vadas with masala in the pan.
Transfer masala vadas to a plate for serving.
Garnish with fresh coriander.

name: Simple and Quick Mawa Recipe

ingredients.name: Milk
ingredients.quantity: Full Cream Milk (Quantity not specified in video, but implied as main ingredient.)

instructions: Boil the milk in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium heat.
Stir the milk frequently to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pan.
Continue to simmer and stir the milk until most of the water evaporates and it thickens into a solid mass.
Scrape the sides of the pan regularly to incorporate the milk solids back into the mixture.
Once the mawa has thickened and reduced significantly, continue cooking until it forms a dough-like consistency.
Ensure all the moisture has evaporated and the mawa is dry.
Remove from heat and let it cool completely.
Use the mawa as a base for various sweets.
description: Simple and Quick Mawa Recipe – No Preservatives, 100% Pure. You’ll Never Buy Mawa Again After Watching This Recipe

name: Lauki ka Halwa

ingredients.name: Lauki (Gourd)
ingredients.quantity: 750g (approx.) shredded or grated Lauki/Gourd after peeling and removing the seeds and the soft pith portion. The weight refers to the raw, unprepared gourd.) Note: The recipe calls for 'Lauki' which is also known as bottle gourd or opo squash. Ensure you use the correct vegetable for this recipe. The quantity is approximate as the size of gourds can vary. You need enough to fill the pressure cooker adequately for the halwa to cook properly. Adjust the other ingredients accordingly based on the amount of lauki you have.)

ingredients.name: Ghee
ingredients.quantity: 2 tsp + 1 tbsp (The recipe uses ghee at two different stages: 2 tsp initially and 1 tbsp later.)

ingredients.name: Malai (Cream)
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (Malai is the layer of cream that forms on top of boiled milk. In this recipe, it is used to add richness and flavor to the halwa. If fresh malai is not available, you can substitute it with heavy cream or evaporated milk, but the taste and texture may vary slightly.)

ingredients.name: Cashews
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (These are used as a garnish and to add a nutty flavor and texture to the halwa. You can use whole cashews or chop them into smaller pieces. You can also substitute them with other nuts like almonds or pistachios.)

ingredients.name: Almond Flakes
ingredients.quantity: 2 tbsp (These are used as a garnish and to add a nutty flavor and texture to the halwa. You can use whole almonds or slice them into flakes. You can also substitute them with other nuts like cashews or pistachios.)

ingredients.name: Raisins
ingredients.quantity: 1 tbsp (These are used as a garnish and to add a sweet and chewy element to the halwa. You can use any type of raisins, such as golden raisins or black raisins. You can also substitute them with other dried fruits like chopped dates or dried cranberries.)

ingredients.name: Sugar
ingredients.quantity: ¾ cup (150g) (The amount of sugar can be adjusted to your taste preference. If you prefer a less sweet halwa, you can reduce the amount of sugar. If you prefer a sweeter halwa, you can increase the amount of sugar. You can also use other sweeteners like jaggery or honey.)

ingredients.name: Cardamom Powder
ingredients.quantity: ½ tsp (This is used to add a warm and aromatic flavor to the halwa. You can use freshly ground cardamom powder or store-bought cardamom powder. You can also substitute it with other spices like nutmeg or cinnamon.)

instructions: Prepare the Lauki: Peel the lauki, remove the seeds, and grate it. Ensure you are using the correct vegetable, also known as bottle gourd or opo squash.
Cook the Lauki: In a pressure cooker, add 2 tsp of ghee and the grated lauki. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Add Malai: Add 1 cup of malai (cream) to the lauki in the pressure cooker. Mix well.
Pressure Cook: Close the pressure cooker and cook for 2 whistles on high heat. Then, reduce the heat to low and cook for another 5-7 minutes.
Open and Sauté: Open the pressure cooker after the pressure has released naturally. Sauté the mixture until the moisture evaporates.
Add Ghee and Sugar: Add 1 tbsp of ghee and ¾ cup (150g) of sugar. Mix well and sauté until the sugar dissolves and the mixture thickens.
Add Cardamom Powder: Add ½ tsp of cardamom powder and mix well.
Garnish: Garnish with 2 tbsp of cashews, 2 tbsp of almond flakes, and 1 tbsp of raisins.
Serve: Serve hot and enjoy!
description: Lauki ka Halwa is a traditional Indian sweet dish made from bottle gourd, ghee, sugar, and nuts. This recipe is a quick and easy version made in a pressure cooker without using mawa or milk powder.

name: Lauki Jowar Thepla
instructions: Grate the lauki (gourd).

In a mixing bowl, combine the grated lauki, jowar flour, wheat flour, besan, salt, curd, chopped green chilli, grated ginger, turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chilli powder, cumin powder, ajwain, kasuri methi, chopped green coriander, and oil.
Mix well and knead into a soft dough. Add water if needed.
Divide the dough into equal portions and roll each portion into a small circle.
Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat.
Place the rolled thepla on the hot tawa and cook until golden brown on both sides, using oil as needed.
Serve hot with curd or chutney.

name: Baby Corn Masala Curry
instructions: Prepare the ingredients: Chop baby corn, tomatoes, ginger, and green chili.
Make a paste of tomatoes, green chili, ginger, and cashews.
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds, bay leaf, and asafoetida.
Add the tomato-cashew paste and cook until the oil separates.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and coriander powder. Cook for a minute.
Add the baby corn and salt. Mix well and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add water to adjust the gravy consistency. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Add dry fenugreek leaves and fresh cream. Mix well.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with roti, paratha, puri, or rice.
description: A rich and flavorful baby corn curry made in a creamy gravy, perfect for dinner, parties, and special occasions.

name: Makhana Mewa Paag

ingredients.name: Makhana (Fox Nuts)
ingredients.quantity:
2 cups (50 grams each, total 100 grams approx.)

instructions: To begin, heat a pan over medium heat.
Add makhana (fox nuts) and roast them until they are crisp and slightly golden.
Transfer the roasted makhana to a plate and set aside.
In the same pan, add ghee and let it melt.
Add chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, pistachios) to the ghee and sauté until lightly golden.
Remove the nuts from the pan and set aside.
In the same pan, add sugar and water.
Stir continuously until the sugar dissolves completely.
Allow the syrup to simmer until it reaches a one-string consistency.
To check the consistency, take a small amount of syrup between your thumb and index finger and gently pull them apart. If a single string forms, the syrup is ready.
Reduce the heat to low and add the roasted makhana and sautéed nuts to the syrup.
Mix well to ensure that the makhana and nuts are evenly coated with the syrup.
Continue to cook on low heat, stirring constantly, until the syrup thickens and coats the makhana and nuts completely.
Once the mixture starts to leave the sides of the pan and forms a soft, sticky mass, turn off the heat.
Transfer the makhana mixture to a greased plate or tray.
Spread it evenly and let it cool completely.
Once cooled, cut the makhana paag into desired shapes (squares, diamonds, or any other shape).
Store the makhana paag in an airtight container at room temperature.
Enjoy the delicious and traditional Makhana Mewa Paag as a sweet treat during Janmashtami or any other festive occasion!
description: Traditional Makhana Paag for Krishna’s Bhog, Fasting Sweet That Doubles the Festive Joy, Most Delicious Fasting Sweet

name: Makar Sankranti Recipes | Pongal Festival Recipes
instructions: This is a collection of pongal festival or makar sankranti recipes which covers both South Indian and North Indian food.
The collection includes sakkarai pongal, paal pongal, vellai pongal, kalkandu pongal and more varieties of sweet pongal recipes and few snacks like vadai and lunch recipes too.
Sakkarai Pongal is made traditionally during Pongal festival or Makar Sankaranti as the first meal with the first harvested rice of the year.
Pongal is made in the east direction facing Sun which symbolizes thanks giving & dedication of the first meal from the harvest to Sun God for a bountiful harvest.
The significance of using raw rice instead of boiled rice for making Pongal is that first cooking with the harvest is celebrated & dedicated to Sun God.
Sweet pongal can be made using 2 methods the traditional pot method or pressure cooker method.
Sweet pongal or sakkarai pongal is my most favorite and I make it atleast once a month.
Sakkarai pongal recipe a delicious Indian sweet made with rice, jaggery, moong dal, ghee and nuts.
Easy sweet pongal recipe made in pressure cooker.
Traditionally sweet pongal is made with just jaggery rice and moong dal as main ingredients.
Milk is optional to add or not.
We serve sakkarai pongal in vazhailai(banana leaf).
During poojas or any auspicious days we can make this sweet pongal and offer as neiveidhyam for god.
Many south indian household have the custom of making sweet pongal on fridays apart from festival days like pongal.
Pongal can be made using pressure cooker or bronze pot.
The traditional method of making sweet pongal in villages is to use brass or mud pots, they use viragu adupu(woodfire) to make it.
Apart from Pongal festival, Sweet Pongal is made for occasions like house warming, baby shower, anniversary, birthday, prasad in temples, annadhanam, aadi month, auspicious Fridays, sweet craving
Sweet Pongal is delicious, yummy dish made by cooking rice & moong dal in milk, water & jaggery syrup and then flavoured with ghee and cashews.
During poojas or any auspicious days we can make this sakkarai pongal and offer as neiveidhyam tor god.
Many south indian household have the custom of making sweet pongal on fridays apart from festival days like pongal.
Makar sankranti is a festival in Hindu calendar which falls on January 14th or 15th every year.
Makar Sankranti festival is dedicated to Sun God.
We call it by many names and is a multi cultural festival celebrated all over India.
Makar Sankranti is celebrated in the month of January every year to mark the winter solstice.
It is one of the popular and largely celebrated festivals in India.

Recipes include Apple Fizz, Baked Mac and Cheese, Christmas Cookies, Bon Bons, Snickerdoodle Cookies, Honey Joys, and Christmas Cornflake Wreath Cookies.
Other recipes include Pori Kadalai, Ragi Powder, Navaratri Recipes, Navratri Sundal Recipes, Ganesh Chaturthi Recipes, Gokulashtami Recipes, Onam Sadhya, and Karthigai Deepam Recipes.

name: Brain Fry Recipe
instructions: First rinse the brain well, then remove the red vein part as shown below.
Then rinse it again with turmeric and set aside. Get the chopping done.
Now add all the ingredients given under 'to grind' to the mixer jar and add little water.
Grind it a semi fine paste. Set aside.
Heat oil in a kadai add cinnamon, cloves then curry leaves, let it splutter.
Then add chopped onion, garlic.
Saute till it becomes transparent. Then add brain with a pinch of turmeric powder. Just toss it.
Now add the masala paste, add ¼ cup water and let it cook for 5mins in low flame. Cook until raw smell of the masalas leave. Brain will get cooked faster.
Cook until it becomes semi dry, it will take just 3-5 minutes. Garnish with coriander leaves and switch off. Enjoy Brain Fry!

name: Karupatti Coffee Recipe (Karupatti Kaapi)

ingredients.name: karupatti
ingredients.quantity: to taste (inferred from recipe name and context, likely a few pieces or spoonfuls per cup of coffee strength desired.)

ingredients.name: coffee
ingredients.quantity: to taste (inferred from recipe name and context, likely a teaspoon or more per cup of coffee strength desired.)

instructions: Boil water.
Add coffee and karupatti to the boiling water.
Simmer for a few minutes, allowing the karupatti to dissolve and the coffee to brew.
Strain the coffee to remove any undissolved particles.
Serve hot.
description: A traditional South Indian coffee made with palm jaggery (karupatti).

name: Quinoa Upma
instructions: Measure quinoa, rinse it in water at least twice then soak in water for at least 15mins.
Drain water and set the quinoa aside. Heat oil in a pan add the item listed under 'to temper', then add onion and saute for 2mins until it becomes transparent.
Then add carrot and peas, saute for a minute then add quinoa. Add required salt.
Saute for a minute, then add water.
Let it come to a boil, then cook covered for at least 15-20 mins in lowest flame, Check after 15mins then proceed further if needed.
Fluff it up, the grain will be seen transparent with a tiny tail, that ensure proper cooking. Switch off. Quinoa Upma Ready!
description: Quinoa upma recipe with step by step photos featured in this post. Quinoa upma is a healthy quick breakfast made by cooking quinoa with tempered onions, mixed vegetables and spices. Quinoa upma is a good choice for those who wish to experiment different recipes with different ingredients.

name: Panai Olai Kozhukattai
instructions: First crush palm jaggery, I used my hand mortar and pestle. Measure and transfer crushed palm jaggery to a pan.
Add water till immersing level. Crush it well using a potato masher.
Heat it up and cook for few minutes until the jaggery melts completely. Strain to remove impurities. Cool down for later use.
Wash the palm leaves, cut the center portion about 4 to 5 inches long and set aside. Dry roast green gram dal till slightly browned. Cool down for few minutes.
Transfer to a mixer and grind to a coarse mixture. Now in a bowl add rice flour, green gram mixture, grated coconut and cardamom powder.
Mix it well, I transferred it to a wider bowl. Then add palm jaggery syrup little by little.
Keep mixing and the syrup fully, mix well. If it is still dry, sprinkle little water to form a dough like this, not too dry and not too gooey.
Gather it together to form a dough. Open the palm leaf, grease it with oil, now stuff it with the dough lengthwise.
Tie it with a thread, I used palm leaf threads itself. Finish all the dough like this. Now arrange it in a steamer pot, I used my idli steamer.
As a final step steam it for at least 15-20 minutes. Open and carefully remove the kozhukattais from the palm leaf.
Serve Pani Olai Kozhukattai hot!

name: Pori Upma Recipe | Puffed Rice Upma Recipe
instructions: In a pan heat oil in pan - add the items listed under 'to temper' let it splutter, then add peanuts roast until crisp.Then add onion saute till transparent then add carrot,turmeric powder.
Saute for 2-3 minutes.Meanwhile take pori in a strainer.
Rinse it once,squeeze excess water and add it to the pan.Toss it well.Alternatively you can soak for 2 minutes then squeeze excess water too.
Serve Pori Upma hot / warm!

name: Sambar Vada

ingredients.name: urad dal
ingredients.quantity: ½ cup (or more as needed for desired quantity of vadas.)

ingredients.name: water
ingredients.quantity: as needed for soaking and grinding dal

instructions: Rinse urad dal twice, then soak for 2 to 3 hours at least.
Then add it to wet grinder & grind it with very little water to a thick batter. Scrap the sides every now and then.
Grind it for at least 30 minutes. When you take a pinch of the batter and put it in water, it should float that's the right consistency. The batter should be more like butter very smooth and light.
Now transfer the batter to a mixing bowl, add chopped onion, curry leaves and whole pepper. Mix well. Add required salt.
Now take a lemon sized ball, using your thumb finger make a small hole in the center like shown.
Heat oil, add the vadai into the oil. Similarly make other vadais too. As I used my small kadai I fried only 2 vadais at a time. Fry till golden.
Prepare all the vadais similarly and make it ready.
Now take ¼ cup sambar in a bowl, add little hot water and dilute it.
Now add the prepared vadais into the diluted sambar, soak it for 2 minutes, then take it out and place it in the serving plate.
Now pour thick hot sambar over it.
Add chopped onion, sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Serve Sambar Vada hot!
description: Sambar Vada is nothing but medhu vadai dunked in hot sambar with chopped raw onion and coriander leaves. Sambar Vada is recipe made with basic ingredients. It's just crispy medu vadas soaked in hot sambar till they turn all soft and juicy. The vadas soak up sambar for few minutes, it turns soft inside but still holds a tiny bite outside makes it so tasty.

name: Drumstick Leaves Powder | Moringa Leaves Powder

ingredients.name: drumstick leaves
ingredients.quantity: N/A (as needed for powdering process, inferring large quantity to start with for yield after drying/grinding.)

instructions: Wash drumstick leaves thoroughly.
Spread the leaves on a clean cloth or tray and allow them to dry completely in a shaded area. Ensure no moisture remains to prevent mold.
Once the leaves are fully dried and crisp, grind them using a mixer or grinder until you obtain a fine powder.
Sieve the powder to ensure a smooth texture.
Store the drumstick leaves powder in an airtight container in a cool, dry place.
description: Recipe for making drumstick leaves powder (moringa leaves powder).

name: Schezwan Egg Fried Rice

ingredients.name: basmati rice
ingredients.quantity: ¼ cup uncooked rice / ~1 cup cooked rice (estimated based on rice expansion during cooking process.)

instructions: Soak red chillies in little hot water for an hour, transfer it along with water to a mixer jar then grind it to a fine paste, set aside.
Pressure cook rice with enough water for 3 to 4 whistles.
Fluff the rice, add little oil and set aside.
In a pan heat oil - add chopped garlic and spring onion white part, sauté for a minute.
Then add onion sauté till it turns transparent.
Add chili paste, soya sauce then add carrot and cabbage and sauté in medium high flame for 2 minutes.
Then lower the flame and sauté for few mins until the vegetables shrink then add capsicum and sauté for 2 minutes.
Finally add egg, scramble it well.
Now add required salt and pepper powder. Sauté for a minute, then add cooked rice.
Toss it well finally add spring onions green part toss it well and cook for 2mins.
Garnish with chopped spring onions and Serve Schezwan Egg Fried Rice hot with your choice of side dish or any manchurian.

name: Sago Murukku | Javvarisi Murukku

ingredients.name: sago
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: rice flour
ingredients.quantity: 1 cup (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: urad dal flour
ingredients.quantity: 1/4 cup (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: butter
ingredients.quantity: 2 tablespoons (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: cumin seeds
ingredients.quantity: 1 teaspoon (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: asafoetida
ingredients.quantity: a pinch (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: salt
ingredients.quantity: to taste (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

ingredients.name: oil
ingredients.quantity: for deep frying (approximate, based on similar recipes and images from the page, actual recipe is missing from the provided content.)

instructions: Soak sago in water for about 2 hours.
Drain the water completely from the sago.
In a bowl, mix together sago, rice flour, urad dal flour, butter, cumin seeds, asafoetida, and salt.
Add water gradually and knead into a soft dough.
Heat oil in a pan for deep frying.
Fill the murukku press with the dough.
Press the murukku into hot oil in circular motions.
Fry until golden brown and crisp.
Remove from oil and drain on paper towels.
Store in an airtight container.
description: Sago Murukku (Javvarisi Murukku) is a crispy and savory snack made with sago, rice flour, and spices.

name: How to Make Asafoetida | Homemade Hing Recipe

ingredients.name: compound hing
ingredients.quantity: 100 grams (2 small blocks used in example recipe steps below.)

ingredients.name: asafoetida
ingredients.quantity: 100 grams (2 small blocks used in example recipe steps below.)

instructions: Take compound hing (asafoetida), stretch it a bit. I used 2 small blocks.
Cut into small pieces. It is a bit hard but you can cut it using a sharp scissor.
All cut and ready.
Add it to a pan and dry roast it.
Roast until it is crisp and puffs up. It takes around 8-10 minutes in low flame.
Cool down completely.
Transfer to a mixer jar.
Grind it to a fine powder.
Transfer to a plate, cool down completely. Store in a clean dry jar.
description: A recipe for making asafoetida powder at home.

name: Egg Puffs

ingredients.name: puff pastry sheets
ingredients.quantity: 5 sheets (5'X5' frozen puff pastry sheet used in recipe example, but size may vary.)

ingredients.name: boiled eggs
ingredients.quantity: 3 large eggs, halved, yolk side down in assembly shown in example recipe instructions.

instructions: To a pan heat 1 and ½ tablespoon oil , add 2 medium sized onion(sliced).
Saute until it turns transparent then add 1 teaspoon ginger garlic paste.
Saute for 2 minutes.
Cook covered until it turns soft.
Now give a quick sauté then add salt to taste, 1 and ½ teaspoon chili powder, ¼ teaspoon turmeric powder, ½ teaspoon pepper powder and ½ teaspoon garam masala powder.
Saute well for a minute then add ½ cup water.
Saute and cook for 2 minutes.
Add 1 tablespoon tomato sauce and few curry leaves torn.
Give a quick mix and switch off.
Boil eggs slice into half and keep it ready. Transfer the filling to a bowl and set aside to cool. Both filling and eggs are ready.
Take a puff pastry sheet. I have used 5'X5' frozen puff pastry sheet. Dip your finger with water and wet the edges first.
Add around 2 tablespoon onion filling first then add half an egg with yoke side facing down like shown.
Close from the sides like shown. While you do this preheat oven at 200 DEG C for 10 minutes.
Close from all four sides and seal completely. Repeat to finish.
Beat an egg well, dip using a brush.
Give egg wash for all.
Repeat to finish.
Bake in preheated oven at 200 DEG C for 20-25 minutes.
Serve it hot!

name: Kambu Maavu Puttu
instructions: Dry roast the flour until aroma comes, my flour was already roasted so just roasted for a minute and proceeded.
Now sprinkle water may 2 tablespoon.
Mix well without any lumps, try to hold the flour tightly with your hands if it holds then this is the right consistency, stop adding water.
Transfer the flour to a steamer plate and steam for at least 15-20 minutes in low medium flame. The color of the flour must have changed by now.
Transfer it to a mixing bowl add cane sugar, cardamom powder, ghee, sugar and salt.
Mix well. Serve Kambu Maavu Puttu hot / warm!
description: Kambu Maavu Puttu is a mild sweet dish made using pearl millet flour which is steamed and then mixed with sugar, coconut and ghee. This recipe has soft crumbly texture that melts easily in your mouth and gives nice nutty flavor from the millet. I make this when I want something simple but still healthy to eat, mostly for breakfast or even sometimes for light dinner.

name: Black Tea
instructions: Boil water well.
Add tea powder.
Boil for at least 3 mins.
The color changes to darker shade.
Look at the color.
Switch off.
Remove from flame, close with lid and set aside for few mins for all the flavours to steep in.
Now add sugar.
Strain and add black tea to it.
Mix well.
Add to serving glass and serve Black tea hot!
